< Text>
This is a solid airport hotel. Much better than most. Good Platinum recognition with an upgrade to a suite of some sort -- really a very big room with a couch and table... very small normal bathroom though.

I used the lobby area to do some work. The lobby area is well setup for people to meet, converse or get some work done. i left my laptop case there and later went down to look for it and it was gone. Called lost and found and luckily it had been found by a hotel employee and was promptly returned to my room!

The reason why I was using the lobby was that the internet in the room was painfully slow, and was very fast in the lobby. I called tech support on the internet and was transferred to the offsite vendor who walked thru a script, including asking me for a contact number -- wouldn't you think that if you had just been transferred to them from the Sheraton Gateway, they would know the phone number to call if they had to call you back -- they did "reboot" the local router and the service did "improve" although it was far too slow, hence heading to the lobby, as I didn't have the time or the patience to talk to someone in a call center, rather than someone in the hotel who might have been more equipped to handle the problem.

Had a breakfast in the Brasserie the next morning. Ordered off the menu. Service was good, but I'd have to say that the food was only just OK!

Anyway, I wouldn't hesitate to stay there again for a quick stay if I needed to around LAX -- would venture further out for a more extended stay.</Text>

We stayed just 1 night so we could catch our flight home the next day. The hotel is very close to LAX with the shuttle bus to Terminal 2 being less than 5 minutes. The shuttle ran regularly with no issues. I had rented a vehicle from Budget for our trip and after dropping the family off at the hotel I returned it and I was able to literally walk the 1 block back to the hotel. The outdoor pool has a fire pit and a few fire lanterns that really added to the environment. Lastly, the hotel obviously has high efficiency noise reducing windows as you seldom and barely heard planes. Only negative was that as a gold member I was not upgraded or even placed on a Starwood Preferred Guest floor. Disappointing though not the end of the world. Overall, good stay for our purposes.< /Text>

< Name>
sqg13<//Name>
< date>
1472083200000< /date>
<Rating>None< /Rating><review>Location: Right by the Century Boulevard. Very close to LAX (about one mile to most of the terminal). The hotel provides a complimentary shuttle, which runs every 15 minutes. However, the shuttle is shared with an airport parking facility by the hotel and I could hardly recognize the shuttle before it ran past me, twice. I ended up walking from Terminal 3 for about 15 minutes to the hotel, not bad at all. The hotel is also close to the famous plane spotting location in-n-out burger, with 15 minutes of walking from the hotel.

Check-in: Professional staff. Although they could not check me in before 3pm, I got to check my luggage with a concierge. My booking is a club-level room, with request facing the runway (to be exact, the south runways 25L/R). They seemed to run out of room of my choice, so the agent proposed a corner room with "city view" and ensure me that I can see the plane landing. I ended up taking the room. It did not disappoint me since the north runways are where most heavy planes take off and land and it was a joy to be able to watch them from my room.

Room: spacious, clean, recently refurbished with a fresh smell of new furnitures. The "city view" is much better that it sounds, with a full view of downtown Los Angeles and Santa Monica in distance. Again, you can see planes on final approach to runway 24R and many of them are jumbo jets. Walking out side of the room you can see planes touching down and taking off on 24L/R. The window glass and wall are high quality sound proof, so you would not likely be bothered by heavy jets flying by. The bed is very comfy to me as in most Sheraton hotels I've stayed in. I like the 50 inch TV, definitely bigger than those in many older Sheraton hotels. The internet is not the fastest that I had in SPG properties, but good enough with 5mbps. If your booking does not include Internet, it would cost $12.95 each night.

Club: To get to the club floor and club room, you either book a club-floor room, or you are a SPG platinum member. This club is very spacious, almost twice as large as a traditional Sheraton club lounge. The club has a row of window seats, facing runways 25L/R, perfect for aviation geeks like me. This Sheraton club offers daily breakfast, all-day snacks, coffee, tea, soda and bottle water, plus an evening appetizer. For breakfast, there were hot eggs, pastries and fruits (no potatoes or breakfast meat), with an alternative of congee. For evening appetizers there were no meat either (I've had BBQ chicken wings at other Sheraton clubs). For me, I do not eat a big breakfast and eat a small dinner, nor do I care what to eat. Thus I am OK with the club food, but it would be much nicer if one meat option was provided for breakfast and dinner.</review><pictures>None</pictures><response>None</response><GmapID>0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d< /GmapID></record>
</dataset><record>

<Resp>None< /Resp>< text>
WARNING, LOUD JACKHAMMERING GOING ON IN THE HALLWAY ALL DAY. LONG. I COULD BARELY HEAR THE PERSON AT THE CHECK IN DESK. EAR PROTECTION SHOULD HAVE BEEN PROVIDED! The place is crazy-chaotic outside at valet parking, "self" parking isn't even on the premises (though I was told when I called the hotel to book a few days before that it was on the premises!) and still you have to pay for it. Worse still was the shock when entering the lobby: it's almost pitch dark in there! What kind of supposedly upscale hotel chooses to make its lobby look like Purgatory's warehouse? Gray, and gloomy and no luxury feel at all. Plus you have to walk way to the back of the building to get to the "front desk" for check in, which is really two tiny desks that look and feel more like TSA check in counters only less lighted. The walk to the elevators was completely maze-like and then you have to squeeze into this strangely shaped tiny area to get to them to get up to the room levels. Once there, things do not get better. The room was also very dark and gloomy. There were not enough towels provided. No extra blankets. NO REFRIGERATOR! There were two bottles of water placed neatly on the desk for you but watch out because if you're tired and thirsty you might not notice until you open them that you will be charged for them. The bathroom was very tiny and the tub old looking. Oh and a couple of times I tried to call down to room service or front desk and no one ever answered. There were one or two nice staff people and that was about it. Several things I was promised about the hotel and about my reservation turned out not to be true. How do you book a reservation and boldy lie to the client? I just don't get that. Also, shouldn't a business be required to tell you when you are booking in a place that will be having jackhammering going on so that you can opt to book elsewhere?? Really, just not a good hotel *at all*. The only thing it has going for it is that it is close to the airport. Seriously.< /text>

< text>
Great location of hotel next to LAX airport for those needing a quick arrival or departure; however, this and other Sheraton's I have stayed seem to need updates/upgrades to their room decor and bathrooms. The bathrooms are poorly lit and the showers slow to drain. I've stayed at 2 different Sheraton's during the last month and both bathrooms smelled like mold. The pink/red mold on the shower curtain was clearly visible so not sure why those aren't replaced regularly by housekeeping. Surely it can be seen and smelled. Other than that, this particular hotel location worked out great for us as the shuttle ride to the airport was less than 5 minutes.< /text>

< Review>
The LAX Sheraton has to be about the best-run Sheraton in the Starwood chain. From a very nice SPG Gold upgrade from Arlene upon arrival (on a promotional rate) to the excellent service in the Basserie, the LAX Sheraton could give a lesson in service to plenty of other hotels. < review>
I had 2 different reservation confirmations which the hotel refused to merge and required me to come down to the desk to check out and check back in. I found that to be an extreme inconvenience, as I was scheduled to be in a conference all day and did not want to stand in the check in line at the front desk a 2nd time. Had I known that (before my arrival), I would have cancelled the 2nd reservation and extended the stay on the 1st reservation for the 2nd night stay.

Because this simple request was not honored, I began to scrutinize other things during my experience. After encountering the rude associate that checked me into the hotel, I noticed that every other associate was great; however, I did find rust in my room's bathtub and holes in the wallpaper in the room.

I am a Starwood member; however, I was not greeted by name or acknowledged as a member.< /review>

<review>While my room and amenities were good, my experience trying to get to the hotel using their complimentary shuttle has turned me off of this property forever. While the phone recording and website say to expect a shuttle every 10-15 minutes, I had to wait over 30 minutes for one to arrive. About halfway through, I had called the hotel to see if there was a delay or if they knew what was going on. I was first transferred to dispatch where I stayed on hold for a few minutes listening to the recording that all dispatch agents were busy. When I gave up and called back, the operator said to just take a taxi and ask to be reimbursed at the front desk. Mind you, that would require me to leave the shuttle area and wait on the taxi line, but it would be most unfair to the taxi driver who was probably waiting hours for a fare only to come up in the queue and have a $5 ride half a mile away. I expressed my frustration and the unfairness of that proposal to the operator and asked to speak to a manager at which point she said ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt deal with you‚Äù and hung up on me. This was a totally unacceptable response from someone in customer service. Once I finally got on the shuttle bus, it took another 30 minutes to circle the airport and make its way to the hotel after picking up and dropping off a number of other passengers. I will note that the hotel co-brands its shuttles with a local parking lot. So don‚Äôt expect to see the traditional Sheraton branding colors and the logo is somewhat diminished compared to the parking lot. This is a missed opportunity in my book since many of the other hotel chains don‚Äôt share their shuttles with off-site parking lots. I explained my experience to the manager on duty and he was apologetic regarding my experience and said it wasn‚Äôt the type of service they strive towards. Based on my platinum status I was upgraded to a nice corner suite, which would be nice if I was staying longer than a quick overnight. Overall, I can‚Äôt recommend this hotel unless they fix some of their shuttle logistics. The only reason I stayed at this hotel was based on the proximity to the airport and ease of access to a complimentary shuttle. Given the main reason I opted to stay at this hotel was the biggest issue, I doubt I would stay again. I would rather stay at any of the other hotels that had shuttles constantly passing me like the Embassy Suites, Sheraton Four Points, or Hyatt Regency.<//review>< Pictures>
None<//Pictures>

<review>I have to start quoting one of the reviewers: "This is hard for me because I love Starwood and I love the Sheraton brand (...). I am fortunate to be a Starwood Platinum Member (...), so it is with a heavy heart to have to bring a complaint to the public view". Just some more: I travel a lot - at least once weekly, and I use many hotel brands, mainly across Europe (of course Starwood is my favourite brand). So I have quite a good knowledge what does "good enough" standard mean. And my expectations are not very high - I just want to have a clean and quiet room and friendly (not "intrusive") staff.

I was positively surprised with the special line for SPG Gold and Platinum (it does not happen very often), and that was generally all. The receptionist seemed to be tired, she recited the welcome lines, never asked for the amenity I want to choose. Fact - there were a lot of coming guests and one could be tired, but the next day another receptionist behaved more or less the same way - also having problems to print the invoice with my company details. I have asked for the scales to check my luggage weight - this is airport hotel (bthw. I was surprised that in Sheraton there were no scales in the bathroom). The guy from the concierge seemed not to be happy with my request. Basically I do not need to much warmth - but I would expect something more from Sheraton staff.

And from the airport hotel one would expect better noise insulation - here I can give the example from one of the competitive brands hotel in Zurich, where windows are very vell protecting from plane noise.

I wouldn't be honest not mentioning positives: very clean room, good bed quality, nice lounge, very helpful valet parking staff and convenience in terms of airport distance. So if you need a convenient and price-efficient hotel close to the LAX airport - that might be a good choice.< /review>< Pictures>
None< /Pictures>

<user>None<//user><Name>Sunsh9<//Name><date>1399420800000< /date><Rate>None< /Rate><text>I have selected this property for my weekly business stays out of a short list of 4 SPG properties in the area.

The staff here is awesome, from the front desk, guest services, restaurant to the valet staff; I have no complaints.

The hotel can improve in a few areas - the noise from neighboring rooms can be excessive and the restaurant prices are on the high side. I have experience very loud neighbors late into the eveing and rowdy guests walking thru the hallways. The walls are very thin and you can hear everything. Possibly a notice to guests to try to courtesy of others and refrain from letting doors slam shut would be helpful.

I ordered dinner ONCE and it was tasty but not worth the huge price.

Overall, I selected this property because the pros clearly outweight the cons, but if the property is looking for an A+ I would invest in soundproofing the walls, moving the beds away from neighboring doors, or at minimum try to house rowdy airport layover travelers away from the business travelers.

Smile,
Sunshine in the Sunshine State</text><Pics>None< /Pics>< response>

<rating>None< /rating>< text>
I chose this hotel because it was close to the airport. The location is very good for that. It is also quite easy to find, since you have to drive everywhere in LA anyway.

The staff were great. My status was recognized and I was upgraded to a mini-suite. I had a great view of the runways and the sunset. The room was quiet and the bed was comfortable. Everything looked recently updtated.

I ate dinner in Paparazzi, with a colleague. It was fabulous!! The wine list was quite good and very reasonably priced. (Although, it would be better if the years were included on the list, instead of having to ask to waiter, who needed to find someone to provide that information.) The dinner itself was wonderful. Definitely more than I expected from an airport hotel.

I will definitely be returning to this hotel, as the restaurant alone places it above all others on the airport strip.</text>

< user_name>
Ali< /user_name>
< Time>
1577750400000</Time>
<pictures>None<//pictures>< user>
None< /user>
<Response>None< /Response></record>
</dataset><record>
< Text>
I usually stay at the 4 Points Westside. They were sold out so I chose the Sheraton as their self parking was less cost than the nearby Westin. There should be a disclaimer on the hotel site stating that self parking is 1 block away in a public airport long term parking lot. Most of the open spaces are a long long way from the hotel. Plus guests are required to walk a block down a dark street to reach the front of the hotel. I did not feel safe and would not let my daughter park in the lot by herself. Absolutely no security. The in and out pass given by the hotel worked once, then it didn't work anymore. I had to pay to get out. The hotel took the amount off my charges, but it was annoying. When I brought the car around to check out the valet told me if I didn't come back in 15 minutes, they would charge me for valet. After all this, I had a few choice words for the valet. Self parking is $18.00. Valet is $33.00. Total rip off.
At check in, I was told that an upgrade to Club Level was $30.00 even though I am SPG Gold.
The room was clean although there was no free bottled water. The internet was faster than many hotels. The staff didn't seem to care much if I was happy or not.
There are plenty of other choices on this part of town. I would not return to the Sheraton Gateway. If someone doesn't mind paying $33.00 for valet parking or dealing with a staff that doesn't seem to care, then by all means stay here.</Text>

<response>None< /response>< text>
Stayed here in November before a trip from LAX to China. Location to the airport was a prime factor (and it is close) but parking and ease of access is difficult. Since we had a late night flight we decided to keep the room the next day so we could do some sightseeing before we left, then freshen up before the flight. Hotel agreed to this for a modified room charge. The night we were to leave the hotel was very busy with private parties; after we went to dinner hotel wouldn't let us park our car for 15 minutes to get our bags without a $6+ fee, then they tried to charge us twice for the extended room stay. We got the room charge straightened out, but it was a hassle. Additionally, hotel does not have, or did not have available when we were there, a cafe type restaurant where we could get a quick, moderately priced meal. The surrounding neighhborhood is also seemingly devoid of such places. Front desk was no help in this regard.< /text>

<name>Steev99< /name><time>1406851200000<//time><Rate>None<//Rate>< Review>
This used to be my hotel of choice when travelling thru L.A.. Over the last few weeks I have noticed a decline in quality of service and care. After my last stay, I decided to consider other hotel options for my next trip.
Upon arrival and check-in, the front desk staff seemed hurried and overworked. Rather than the friendly welcome that I used to recieve the check in was rushed and impersonal, even though there was no line waiting behind me.I am guessing that this quick process contributed to not receiving the wake-up call that I had requested. I have also noticed that my long standing Gold status no longer gets me the upper level room or extra amenities that it used to. Nothing major, but it was the attention to personal detail that used to keep me coming back.
That said, the staff in the Paparazzi Lounge continue to exceed all expectations in professionalism and service. The experience at Paparazzi remains the primary reason to stay at the Sheraton LAX Gateway. Be sure to stop in and tell them that Steve said "Hello".< /Review>

<text>I stayed at this location twice, before and after a trip to the Dominican Republic. This hotel is a standout. At the beginning of the trip, once I had gotten thru security @LAX, at 5:30 am, I realized I had left a laptop computer in the room. In a panic, I called the hotel, explained my predicament, and was connected right away to the bellhop who had assisted me earlier that morning. Mr. Williamson checked my room, and sure enough found the laptop on the bed. I hopped back on the airport shuttle bus, went back to the Gateway, where Mr. Jorge (sorry I didn't get your last name) was waiting for me at the concierge desk with the laptop. <Name>BusinessTraveler222<//Name><Date>1371168000000< /Date>< Rate>
None< /Rate>
< Review>
Upon entering the facility I was very impressed with out open and updated the lobby area was for a hotel so close to LAX. Rob at check-in was absolutely fantastic and did everything he could to ensure I received an upgraded room.

Overall I was quite impressed with the service of most staff and quality of the hotel, but was extremely disappointed in the valet and room service.

As requested at check-in, I called down 15 minutes ahead each time I needed to take my car out, only to wait an addition 5-10 each time. Once my keys were misplaced and the other two the valet staff informed me that the front desk never called them about my car and that it was a frequent occurrence. For a hotel so closely located to LAX where people are coming in and out and generally in a rush, you'd think they would have this system down. I realize that they're busy down there, but absolutely ridiculous that there was no sense of prioritization upon realizing they they had made a mistake.

I ordered room service one night with a 45 minute delivery which was expected. What wasn't expected was that several of the food items I had ordered were not fulfilled. I was informed that I'd have to wait another 30-45 minutes in order for them to complete the order (would have been after 10:30 PM) and ended up just snacking on what was delivered and leaving the facility (forced to use the slow valet) and finding a meal elsewhere.

Would absolutely stay again due to its proximity to LAX and being one of the nicer SPG properties around the airport, but would likely not valet (or expect a 20 minute wait) and definitely no room service.</Review>

< userid>
115628951738090479172<//userid>
<user_name>David Oswald</user_name><Date>1546512152976<//Date>< rating>
4< /rating>
< Text>
Very close and convenient proximity to LAX airport, including a free shuttle running every 15 minutes. Not much by way of walkable businesses nearby. There are a handful of eateries of varying quality within 2/3rds of a mile, but not really a bustling business district. But for a quick stopover to rest up during our 9 hour layover it was a perfect solution. Longer stays would probably want a vehicle or an account with a ride share service.

Our room was clean. The on site dining was decent faire. There is a Starbucks on site too. While we were there the elevators were always in high demand. I don't know if one or two were out of service or if it's always this way. But we were always able to squeeze in, though a couple times we witnessed others opting to wait for the next one.

There is a small amount of airplane noise, but not objectionable, particularly given the convenience in proximity to the airport. Mostly the sound registered on my mind first as "are those airplanes?" ...and later not noticeable.

If I had another long layover after an international flight and wanted to get some rest I would stay here again without hesitation. If I were a tourist spending time in LA I wouldn't consider proximity to LAX reason enough to forego staying closer to interesting parts of the city (which this is not). If I were in town just on business and my meetings were close by, sure, this place would fit that need well too. The hotel is great, clean, well run, well decorated, and everything you would expect of a big brand hotel in a large city.

For my use case it was also ideal, and I suppose the next time I have a 12 hour flight followed by another couple hours of flying, if I'm unable to get the flights close enough together I will intentionally book them far enough apart that I can do a stop-over here to sleep off some of the jetlag. I was able to arrive home in much better shape than if I had pushed through without rest.<//Text>
< Pictures>
None<//Pictures>

<Review>I am a diabetic and requested a refrigerator in my room, when I made my reservation. I was told I would have one. When I registered, I was told that I had one in my room. I got to my room, no refrigerator! I called down and was told one would be brought right up. I went to dinner and came back, no refrigerator!! I called again and the person on the phone said one would be brought up. I explained that I was previously told that and the man put me through to the manager right away, without even discussing it with me. I know why the manager was an outrageous man.
He told me that refrigerators were on a first come first serve basis and that they were out. I asked him what hotel he was going to purchase a room for me, or was he going to move me to a luxury sweet with a refrigerator? He then started back peddling and said that he would go to housekeeping and look. He said he would call me back in a few minutes. 30 minutes later, I finally called him back and he told me that one was coming.
I explained that no one until him had said that a refrigerator was a first come first serve item and that medical necessity played no part in the process. This was 10:30 pm and with the frustration, I could not get to sleep until 11:30 - way to late.
The next morning, I discovered that I had been charged for the refrigerator (which has never happened in any hotel after explaining my medical need.) I went to the front desk where I was assisted by a very nice young man named Paul. He immediately reversed the charge and gave me some starwood points. He also told me that the hotel policy was that if they could not get a refrigerator, that a bell hop would be sent up and that they could store the medicine in a refrigerator down stairs. (Why hadn't the manager the night before told me that?) Paul also put me in touch with the manager, Mary. When I told her the story, she confirmed the policy that Paul had told me, and said that they never charged for refrigerators on medical necessity.
All in all, the manager soured my taste for your hotel. I would appreciate a response to this. During the entire process, he never apologized for my inconvenience.

The next night I had another problem.

Your staff alwaysed corrected my problems, but I still had problems.

Thanks,

Doug</Review>< Pictures>

< Review>
Upon entering my room, the bathroom soap was already used. 

When I went to use the phone, the red message light was on so I called to retrieve message so light would turn off. There were no messages so I called the operator only to find out there was a phone "upgrade" and some phone lights will never turn off. My phone was one of them. 

To top it off, someone proceeded to unlock my door and walk in 20 min after I did. The front desk had checked him into my room by mistake. As a woman traveling alone, that's a real life nightmare. 

Man went downstairs to get a unoccupied room and I called front desk. I was offered 7,000 points for my trouble. When I checked out two days later, I asked about points and they had no record of that. Luckily the person who checked me out was a woman, sympathized with my situation, and gave me the points that were promised. 

I will never stay at this property again.< /Review>

Great staff and service. Our room which faced Century Blvd was noisy due to planes taking off, noisier than we recalled from our past stays. Maybe the winds or weather had something to do with the louder aircraft noise. Front desk moved us to a quieter room which helped. Management said that the upcoming renovation will improve the sound proofing for those rooms. Otherwise loved the pool, exercise room, and club lounge. We prefer this hotel over other Starwood properties on the west side of Los Angeles.</Review>

< text>
I took the shuttle from the airport which as stated in the phone was only about a 15 minute wait. Upon arrival I was told that my reservation (through Priceline) had been cancelled because the card on file had expired - I got no notification from Priceline whatsoever. I was able to redo my reservation with Sharaton pn the spot but was told I'd have to pay $75 on top of the original price. The next morning after checking, I got an invoice from Sheraton and all I had been charged for was the original Priceline amount. I am very appreciative of this! The rooms were nice - bed was super cozy! And the towels were very soft. Despite being close to the airport, the sound of planes was pretty limited. I did have a room that was adjoines to another, which was a little nervracy. The lock was on my side, so it was fine. The walls within the hotel seemed pretty thin because in the morning I could hear people in the hallway talking, someone knocking on neighborimg doors, and at one point the person in the adjoining room throwing up. Having a Starbucks so close (in the lobby) was really great in the morning. Overall l, my experience with this hotel was very lovely.</text>

< username>
DMKhan</username>
<pics>None<//pics>< text>
Even though our stay was short, it was quite comfortable as the staff in reception. lobby, concierge and Sheraton Club made it quite joyful. Please keep up the "EXCELLENT" service level.
Dr. Mahmoud Khan & Mrs. Amal Alfarsi< /text>
<Rate>None<//Rate></record>
</dataset><record>
<rate>None<//rate><resp>None</resp>< Text>
The hotel has some real strengths but also some areas which need improvement. It seems that this particular hotel is an older hotel and there had been some revamp done in the past. The lobby is nice and has Wi-Fi capability (although it was hard to connect to it at times). Restaurants are adequate and there is a Starbucks and a hotel store on premises. Starbucks prices seems higher than prices at a regular storefront Starbucks and the prices at the hotel store are truly eye-popping. The personnel/staff are very attentive and professional - one of the hotel's strengths. With regards to the rooms, I've booked a traditional King twice so far and notice that the actual main room is all right but it's strange that there is not a room safe to lock away your valuables - you have to bring them down to the front desk to store. Alot of hotels have this simple feature. The room also does not have a fridge which is inconvenient if you want to store and chill water and drinks. The ironing board was truly old and stained. The bathroom appears not to be renovated and is quite old. I had a low pressure toilet issue on my second trip and while maintenance tried to fix it, I was always a little worried about the plumbing. Didn't have the same issue during my first trip but did notice mold on the ceiling at that time. They really need to revamp the bathrooms. The hotel also does not go out of their way to let you know about two really good features - (1.) There is an Ocean Express bus that will take you from a stop near the hotel to Manhattan Beach and some shopping malls and back again for a $5 round trip ticket; and (2.) according to a card in a drawer by the bed, you can get a $5 gift food certificate for use in any restaurant/coffeeshop at the hotel if you choose not to get your linens and towels changed (have to hang a special notice on the doorknob before 2am the night before). Also, you can print out for free your airline ticket at a public computer and printer in the lobby but it's a bit hidden and near the hallway towards the gym. One of the best features of the hotel is their gym. Alot of good equipment. Free shuttlebus to the airport is a great feature.</Text>

1370476800000</Date>

<user_id>None< /user_id><text>I booked my stay for a conference at the hotel two weeks in advance. I asked the booking rep if there is a refrigerator in the room, she said "yes, every room has a refrigerator in it, I will also put your request in the notes so you can be sure to have a refrigerator in your room.
On the day I arrived, as I was driving I called and asked the hotel front desk about my parking options as I forgot to ask at the time of booking. I was told the valet prices versus the lot behind the building. So as I pulled up to the hotel I asked the valet how far of a walk it was from the cheaper lot. They said "oh it's very far and you have to cross the street" so I parked valet. (Just to find out that the next driveway 50 feet away on the same side & same block is the cheaper lot.) WOW!
After check in I find out that not only do I not have a refrigerator, but it's also $20 extra. I got on a waiting list and didn't get one during my whole 3 night stay despite asking often.
Another issue was housekeeping. My first room was not properly cleaned. The tub had a hair on the edge as well as the soap dish had a hair but not from one's head, both from previous guests. The bathroom mirror frame had splatters that looked like toothpaste and paint. Remote control had a thick layer of dirt & dust across one row of buttons. I asked to switch rooms. Had to wait a while for that because they would rather clean than switch you over.
My second room had a bunch of dirt splatters on the bathroom light switch as well as a brown stain on the white bed skirt. I didn't even bother to complain about the second room.
My room keys stopped working and I had to reset them. As I was checking out I had a room charge of $6 for two water bottles in room that I didn't touch.
Over all I wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone who wants a peaceful, pleasant stay.<//text><Rate>None< /Rate><Time>1365984000000</Time><Gmap_id>0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d<//Gmap_id><pictures>None< /pictures>< user_name>

stuck in LAX for a day, i was happily surprised to enjoy a nice, fairly premium experience at the sheraton gateway. details are nicely executed, staff pleasant, abundance of lobby space/meeting space, good sized fitness room and pleasant enough pool area. my only below average mark goes to the bathroom. the shower/bath was old, pressure weak, and shower not properly working. otherwise, all around As.< /Text>

Just ok! Initially paid $120 ish for basic king rm. Decided to upgrade (for $50 more) in order to enjoy a few extra amenities on the club level floors (i.e. continental breakfast --which consisted of mostly pastries...there were boiled & fried eggs, toast 4 bread, coffee, oatmeal and a scary looking hot item that I'm unsure what it was-- also free wifi...yes you'll hv to pay for access to their wifi in their regular rooms). I also valet parked for $49 nightly. It was colder in LA the night of Oct 13th and 14th...only the cold air initially worked in room. Had to request twice for someone to fix AC unit so that heat wld blow out. The room was nice except 1 of my pillows had brown stain on it...so wondered if it was even changed from previous person (the bathroom was nice). I doubt I wld stay here again. They do provide shuttle service to/from airport.</review>

<rating>None</rating><resp>None</resp><user_id>None<//user_id><Pictures>None< /Pictures><review>From the top:

I called their central reservations line because my SPG Starpoints account had gone inactive. First call: I was waiting for 17 minutes before I just hung up. Second call a little while later: I was holding for 15 minutes before I just gave up. Ended up making the reservation online figuring not getting the points was better than spending anymore time on the phone. Apparently checking in itself was supposed to reactivate my account, so we'll see.

Check-in was a breeze. I was able to get a higher floor away from the elevators as requested, which was also nice.

Room was wonderful, clean and comfortable, especially their bed (which Sheraton is known for).

Had a bite to eat at their bar, the sandwich I ordered was delicious! Chicken, provolone and avocado. The fries were only warm, so I didn't eat them. The manager asked me about it and apologized and comped my soda, which was fair.

Here's where things went wrong: When I turned on the shower, the water pressure was very low. I then noticed that a large amount of water was still coming from the faucet, so I fidgeted with it until it stopped, which did seem to help, but I still felt like what should have been a 5 minute shower turned into 20. I called the front desk to see if it was normal (we are in a drought) and they said they didn't think so. I just shrugged it off as I was clean, so didn't see the point in having anything done except telling them they should have engineering check it out before the next guest.

Then, there was the noise level: After 9PM, I could hear constant knocking in the hallway. I want to say that I thought it was housekeeping, but at that time? As this is a hotel airport, I realized that they probably do turn over rooms at all times during the day and not just between noon at 3? Their door latches are quite loud too. I could hear doors closing clearly at least 2 rooms down constantly

What completely ruined my stay: I only paid for a hotel room because I wanted to be refreshed upon returning home and that wasn't going to happen at my friend's home on a futon. I needed uninterrupted sleep. I put the "Quiet Please" sign on my door, unplugged the alarm clock to use that outlet for my cell phone to wake me at 9:30 a.m.. I went to bed at 1 a.m., allowing for 8.5 hours of sleep...until the alarm clock that had been unplugged for at least 6 hours at that point went off at 5:30 in the morning. To say I was confused by being woken up at that time by a strange noise coming from an unlit, unplugged machine would be an understatement. I was so confused, I must of hit the snooze button half asleep, probably believing I was dreaming. Until it woke me again a little later. I couldn't get back to sleep for a while after I turned OFF the alarm clock. Right as I managed to go back to sleep, MY cell phone alarm went off. I was SO exhausted. Just to make sure I wasn't losing my mind, I plugged in the alarm clock long enough to change the alarm time to a minute ahead of the actual time and unplugged it. Sure enough, it went off. Upon checkout, I took the alarm clock down to the front desk, showed the guy there the dark, unpowered alarm clock and waited a minute and it started going off.

The nice guy helping me apologized for the problems I had and said he was going to credit my SPG account 4,000 points. I don't know what that means! A free night? Half a night? Honestly, I was so tired at that point I didn't care. I just wanted to get home ASAP considering I was dead on my feet.

Thankfully, their airport shuttle was prompt and took me to LAX. Unfortunately, I was twice as tired as I was BEFORE my stay here. I know I got a great deal price-wise for the night, but I still ultimately ended up paying money for a bad night's sleep. :o(</review>< Date>
1409702400000<//Date>
< name>
Michael94103<//name>
< Gmap_id>
0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d< /Gmap_id>

< Review>
My business associate and I had a great time staying here for a weekend convention we were attending. The staff was superb and the homeliness was great. There was an unfortunate event with the water supply at the hotel had to be turned off for the majority of a day due to a water main breaking. The staff was very courteous and was giving out water bottles to anyone who needed it -- they even gave away the water that was for sale in the room. The staff was very apologetic during this event. I would go back to this hotel just because of the great way the staff handled the situation.< /Review>

<name>EM2131</name><review>Had an overnight layover in LAX from an international flight so I booked this hotel to get some rest before my next leg. Unfortunately, I didn't get much rest.

No shuttle for the first 40 minutes I waited (supposed to run every 10-15 min) and then when one did come by it just kept driving by. Had to call the hotel and request a shuttle stop for me and the several people also waiting. Finally, after an hour and watching several other hotel shuttles stop several times, our took us to the hotel.

Exhausted, I checked in. Received an upgraded room which was great. Unfortunately, the walls are so thin I couldn't get much sleep. There are paper thin walls and then there is what this hotel has. I woke up several times thinking people were in my room because I could hear the conversations so clearly. 
Not sure what the value of the club was. It doesn't offer anything great.
Only plus was the restaurant was open late and the food was good!

<UserId.>112114496169616845778<//UserId.>< Name>
Alycia Corpiel< /Name>
<Time>1530906189281<//Time><Rating>1<//Rating><review>Your staff had no idea how to answer any of the questions we had and we were not given an overview of hotel amenities at check in.  A front desk agent did not know what an itemized receipt was, nor did she know what a hand towel was.  The bell staff and concierge did not know how to answer simple directions on how to get to a local grocery store and gave me an attitude when I asked for a map of the area.

We were at the event for a conference and had to haul our heavy boxes to our room without assistance of a bell cart because the bellmen wouldn't trust us to bring it back.  I run a low-funded nonprofit and we could not afford to pay a bell person.  My husband and I have worked in the hotel industry for years, those bell carts are some of the least expensive out there.  It was ridiculous that we could not use one for 10 minutes to drop off boxes of heavy items.  We worked at a high-end Hilton resort with 1400 rooms and bell carts worth more than double the worth of the ones at Sheraton Gateway and they were lent out to guests without issue.

Speaking of boxes, if you are going to have conferences in your hotel, you really need to have a pack and ship center.  We shouldn't have to go online, make an account, and then pay a ton of money to print the label at your establishment.  If nothing else, your shuttle should be available to drive us to the local Marriott to ship the items.

On top of all of this, we had to change our room the second day because there was a maggot infestation in the bathroom.  Four people were sent up to my room with no idea of what to do about it.  The first came up when I was not in the room and I had a message on our machine that they didn't come in because we "had a dog".  At check in, I verified we had a rabbit, not a dog, who was penned when in the room and informed the maintenance staff before leaving that they can come in and that the rabbit would be with me downstairs.  I eventually spoke to a manager and had us moved; however, by the time we packed up our stuff the room was given away to another guest so we had to wait for another reassignment.  This time, we were moved to a room that was not up to standards in accordance to the hotel's contract with the Animal Rights National Conference, as our bedding was made with down, aka murdered animal feathers.

"Live plucking causes birds considerable pain and distress. Once their feathers are ripped out, many of the birds, paralyzed with fear, are left with gaping wounds‚Äîsome even die as a result of the procedure. Workers often sew the birds‚Äô skin back together without using any anesthetics.

That‚Äôs not all‚Äîbuying down can also support the cruelty of the foie gras and meat industries because many farmers who raise birds for food make an extra profit by selling their feathers as well. At the slaughterhouse, many of these birds are improperly stunned, which means that they are still conscious when their throats are cut and they are dumped into the scalding-hot water of the defeathering tank." -PETA

Speaking of the conference, when we arrived neither the concierge staff nor the kitchen staff knew of the vegan options offered so we had to order in from another restaurant after a 12 hour day of traveling. We checked in with the conference leads a few days later and they told us that your staff should have been up to date on that information by then.

Oh, and can we talk about the unreliability of the wifi in the meeting rooms?  We bought the code to use at our booth to make credit card transactions and we used up all of our cell phone data because the internet would not hold up.

Finally, your checkout policy is weird.  Most hotels let the guests fulfill the checkout process within an hour of leaving the room.  We were told we could not do this and had to rush to hand over the keys on the way out. Very inconvenient.

If you are going to stay here, be sure to ask for an inside room.  Otherwise, you'll hear planes landing the entire night.

I've stayed at sketchy motels that run better than this hotel.  We will not be staying here again.< /review><Pics>None<//Pics>< Response>
{'time': 1531226190359, 'text': 'I am deeply sorry for any distress and inconvenience caused during your stay and dining experience, as it is our intention to create a welcoming and comfortable environment for each of our guests. We understand your frustrations, and please be advised that your comments are very alarming to us and will be passed along to the appropriate departments. In the meantime, I invite you to reach out to me directly so we can make things right.'}</Response>

<rating>1< /rating>< review>
I had my son's wedding in this hotel. We had a room which had dirty towels on the floor and a messy used bed upon entrance!!! I called the room service at least 6 times and after waiting and disconnecting and transferring so many times, they screamed at me rudely that their system shows the room has been cleaned!!! So, I was lying that there is wet towels in the bathroom's floor with messy beds, apparently!!! Nobody believed me, nobody.... I gave up.... I asked for toilet paper in all my phone calls for the whole stay time but nobody cared.... I gave up again... I had to get in the hallway and find a cart and take one... It made me so angry and upset, knowing it is my son's wedding at this famous hotel and this is how they treat us...   When I found the manager, he told me he will help me in my next stay at this hotel...  Help me? Help me what?? The room was supposed to be with breakfast and they refused the breakfast and at the end they offered a simple breakfast for all this frustration. I will never ever use Sheraton in my future trips, never, very bad experience....< /review>

<Text>It's my go-to-hotel whenever I need to stay near LAX. As an SPG Platinum, I'll usually get an upgrade to whatever they can upgrade me to, without a hassle. Their club lounge always has a decent selection of food & beverages. Their fitness centre has plenty of and a variety of equipment for most workouts. I've never had to wait long for their regular airport shuttle to/from LAX (and they're as close as you can get to the terminals). Easy to get to/from with their location on Century near Sepulveda. Their turn-down service is a class act, when one returns from a day of meetings to find his room ready-to-crash---lights dimmed, curtains closed, duvets pulled back, chocolate waiting. I like that their corproate rates include valet parking, as self-parking there is indeed a p.i.t.a. < Review>
I'm gessing that this was about my eight stay in the past year. I've got a client about 14 miles away; needless to say, I pass quite a few hotels to get to this one. Here, I am treated well - and my impression is that it's not JUST because I'm a regular. The fitness center is fabulous, with windows that open and through which you experience actual sunlight. If you're lucky enough to have access to the Executive Lounge, well, that's nice too. The rooms are well insulated against noise. The only small bummer is that there isn't a hotel-owned parking lot that can be charged to the room folio.</Review>

2. Room Cleanliness

For the most part, the Front Desk Staff was good to us however, the next morning, I went up to one of the Male Front Desk Associates and he looked angry and actually answered a bit angry when I asked him about what steps are required to take my vehicle out of the Self Park Lot. He had a bit of attitude and sounded a bit sarcastic/irritated in regards to my question.

Also, the night we checked in when we got to our room, my girlfriend decided to take a shower and the tub was stuffed up water to her ankles. Fortunately, the staff responded to our needs and took the necessary measures to fix it right away.

The last reason, Self Parking is a bit of an inconvenience. I don't like how far out it is and the fact that Sheraton Getaway shares parking with others. Our clean car also got some sort of brown spots all over the car not sure if it came from Palm Tree in front of vehicle.

Other than that liked everything the Housekeeping and Waiters!</text>< pics>

< Review>
This is not one of the better Sheraton properties. Our room was dated, handles falling off closet door, bathroom needs updating. Self parking is OFF PROPERTY a block away. It seemed very unsafe and I am surprised Sheraton would send their guests to such a facility. No instructions were given by front desk how to use the facility and get the hotel daily rate. Next day we valet the car and was told a reduced price and when we checked out they did not honor the rate we were quoted, The valet manager spoke to us at length and made as feel as the he didnt believe us. The lower rate was honored but it work and a uncomfortable obtaining it. If you need to go to the front desk prepare to wait. Most times it is understaffed. Even when I was in the SPG Preferred section it made no difference. The front desk seemed indifferent and called other guests ahead. Each time at front desk was a min of a 5 min wait. I made the hotel aware of my experience and Mustafo (office manager) emailed stating that some points would be credited the next day. I replied to his email and he didnt respond. When the points did not arrive a month later I emailed Starwood corporate and the points were added to my account. I wont stay at this property next time in LA. The best thing about this is the club lounge. Its better than most and staff very friendly.</Review>

< Name>
spg2345</Name>
< Time>
1378857600000<//Time>
<Rating>None<//Rating><text>The good is that the staff at the hotel seems very friendly and I had no problem with them. Shuttle bus was easy enough for both going to and from hotel, and seems to run every 15-20 minutes.

Unfortunately, that's about it. Rooms were very small (smaller than NYC hotels) and the lighting in the room was terrible. Showers are small, and the shower-head was at my chin/shoulders which meant you needed to squat down to wash your hair. (I'm average height for a male). They did have the curved shower-rod which gave a bit of shoulder room, but it's still extremely cramped.

However, the real kicker is that food prices at the hotel are embarrassingly high. There is a markup on top of the standard hotel markup. There are not many food options nearby, so you are captive to the hotel, which is probably why they can get away with such a high markup.

Club lounge was fair. Attendants very nice, evening spread ok (there was one hot dish), but the breakfast is embarrassing. Food quality fine, but the only protein is hard boiled eggs, no hot items besides oatmeal.

For a very large hotel, you'd expect more. Absolutely a shame since the staff tries very hard, but decisions by management (room layout, pricing, etc.) mean the hotel gets a bad review which ultimately hurts the staff by influencing bookings.</text><pictures>None<//pictures><Response>None< /Response>< GmapID>
0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d<//GmapID>
</record></dataset><record>

<review>This hotel was fine for a quick airport stay. Biggest negative is soundproofing is poor and noise from others opening and closing doors and moving around their rooms was disturbing, as was the air conditioner which went off and on and was quite noisy - room got too warm and then too cold. Also, no fridge or mini bar in room - first hotel we've stayed I for years that didn't have one and amenities weren't great. Lobby was also quite noisy. However, the room and bed were quite comfortable and clean, and the staff was extremely courteous and accommodating - when we called to say the people next to us were making very loud noise and banging doors, security was up in minutes. We would stay again if we needed a hotel near LAX, but do feel there is room for improvement.< /review><Pics>None</Pics>< Response>

< Name>
kazikezawa</Name>
< Review>
So after staying here and feeling pretty unhappy about the stay I decided to let a few days in before I finally decide if I should drop a review or not. Ive decided that the services and overall experience was pretty bad so I have to leave a review.

I arrive at the hotel after a full day of driving from the bay area to meet up with some of my friends who drove from Texas. Our arrival time was about midnight on the date of our reservation.

-checking in-

>Upon reaching the front desk the clerk was noticeably in a bad mood or a hurry or something.
>I try to stay out of her way and just provide my ID and credit card.
>Clerk says in a snappy tone that I am not 21, therefore not allowed to check in.
>I explain I was not aware this specific sheraton had a check in age of 21
>She calls her manager, who also seemed to be in a bad mood told me go somewhere else
>I explain its been a very long day and I just want to rest
>they dont care
>I ask what options do I have
>They tell me either I bring someone whos 21+ or they will cancel and refund my reservations
>I remember I have a friend who is 22 and I tell the front desk I will be right back to get my friend
>amazingly the clerk snapped at me saying how I cant bring someone random off the streets into the hotel.
>I didnt pay much attention to her and went to get my friend
>fast forward 20 minutes and the clerk finally goes through with my reservation but she tells me the room that I had requested for (a double queen) is no longer available.
>(i thought online reservations guarantee the room?)
>clerk offers a single king room
>I explain how we have 5 people and that wont work
>clerk doesnt seem to care and has a take it or leave it attitude
>having no choice I take the room with a rollaway bed
>clerk did not ask for SPG member number

-parking-
>$17 a day for parking
>parking lot is in horrible condition and finding a spot is not guaranteed.

-room-
>room was clean and overall nice
>flatscreen TV had screen problems that made the picture very very dark
>room service request for extra blankets take an hour to arrive
>cramped room for 5 people

-checking out-
>we decided to cut our trip a day short and leave a night in advance because of the inconvenience and discomfort.
>check out clerk was helpful and things went smoothly

Now im sitting here checking my credit card statement and there is an extra $75 from the hotel that was not included in our original room bill and I have to go figure out why theres yet another charge.

-bottom line-
I cant say I recommend this hotel for various reasons. If you are only staying here for a layover or transit I believe that will be just fine for your needs. Avoid if you are coming here for a vacation or getaway.<//Review>

< text>
First of all - Anca at the front desk, is amazing. She was friendly, professional, attentive, and very prompt.

I stay at this hotel frequently, and unfortunately this trip I had to spend Thanksgiving at the LAX Sheraton Gateway. I found it extremely insulting that their signage indicated they were "so thankful" to host guests for a Thanksgiving dinner. For $50.00+ (including 20% tip, tax, and a non-alcoholic beverage". Fifty dollars?? Of course they're thankful for the people being forced to pay that in honor of the US Holiday.

I listened to a man and woman tell their three children that they couldn't afford to have Thanksgiving! I was disgusted. And make no mistake, this was not a hearty sized meal. It was of average proportion, with dry meat.

I overheard the waitstaff joking of the food quality and portions sizes with respect to the Amount being charged to the guests. With the other employee commenting "everything around here is closed, 'they' know what they are doing."

This is unacceptable and SPG Corporate should address this price gouging event.

Please search YouTube for Gateway Sheraton Thanksgiving - I will be posting a video of my bill and the meal that I received.</text>

<time>1493942400000< /time><username>BusinesstravelLC99< /username>< review>
Overall I have been pleased with this Sheraton location & stay there often. However my last stay was horrible. Mostly how the situation was handled. This was a 1 off situation and not typical of this location. During my last stay 1) upon arriving it took over 45 min to get checked in. This was due to an issue with their system being down to create key cards. 2) I wasn't given a key to get into my room. I had to wait another 20 mins for someone to come to my room & let me in my room. 3) Since I was NEVER given a key for my room, I couldn't leave and use the clubroom or the gym. 3) I was told I would get a key but was NEVER given a key. 

As a business traveler where my time is very valuable this was a HUGE inconvenience. I understand things happen but it's how you handle it. The team was basically like there was nothing they could do and treated me like "deal with it". The staff in NO WAY was apologetic or tried to appease guest for the MAJOR inconvenience this system outage cause. I did find it ironic that the system that takes my credit card/money of course wasn't down!< /review>

<rating>None</rating><user>None</user><Response>None<//Response><Date>1334016000000<//Date>< Review>
We last stayed in this Hotel in 2008, but on our recent overnight stay we were terribly disappointed. First of all when we arrived with five bags there was no-one to take our bags or offer to bring them to our room. Secondly when specifically requesting an early check in at time of booking as we were arriving from a 14 hour flight and would only be staying 15 hours we were told that there were absolutely no rooms available and with an unpleasant attitude from the guest assistant. Thirdly the room confirmation states that it has wifi... this is also misleading as it requires an additional surcharge.

On the other hand the room service was extremely fresh and the beds very comfortable.

In the future we will not be choosing the Sheraton Gateway unless the customer service improves out of sight.< /Review>
< Gmap_id>
0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d</Gmap_id>
<Name>franioli12< /Name></record>
</dataset><record>
<time>1474070400000< /time>< review>
The hotel exterior looks really nice and is misleading to the quality. If you want a good night sleep then you shouldn't stay here. If you want to be able to walk to the airport then it is close enough.
The bed was uncomfortable as well as the pillows too flat. Sheets were over starched and felt like poster board. 
It is not well sound insulated for proximity to airport. You will hear people talking in the rooms next to you and all the way down the hall. You will be awoken by airplanes, neighboring rooms and doors opening and closing. 
The adjoining room door was not even secured with a lock, only a safety latch.

You could tell the bathroom was recently updated as the tile in the shower had grout spots hardened up all over which was not comfortable to step on. The cabinet drawers were falling apart.

Restaurant was horribly slow and the food was sub-par for the price.

Front desk staff and concierge were horrible. Very inefficient and not helpful. The concierge had no information about restaurants or events happening close by.

I recommend this hotel for outdoor activities since you won't have to be at the hotel.<//review>

<user_id>None< /user_id>< user_name>
Tahoesusan<//user_name>
<time>1463356800000</time><Rate>None<//Rate>< Review>
We arrived and check-in was smooth. We self-parked the car as valet was $45 a night and self park was $17. The parking is across the street in the back of the hotel which as a female can be a little scary.

 The food choices are underwhelming. The bar or the Brassiere are the current restaurants. They do have a Starbucks that also sells food. Prices are typical for a hotel. The tuna poke was outstanding and is currently a special. Noodle soup was too salty, hamburger nothing special, onion soup served with croutons instead of toasted piece of bread. It made the soup soggy along with the fact it was also very salty and I like salt. We stayed on the Club level and had a great view. 

The room was nice but we had issues with the sink water which tasted like sulfur. We did complain and they adjusted are bill. They said there plummer is being renovated so it could be from that. We also had someone open our door during the night and they were going to check videos to see what happened. We received a credit and points for our inconvenience. 

The club was o.k. Breakfast eggs were barely warm, same with the egg rolls served as hor d'oeuvres. They had a machine that made lattes and other specialty coffees. Facilities there were very nice but they don't have a microwave there to make food hot and they weren't so accommodating. I asked for a plastic cup and they said they didn't have even though they have in the evenings. These are minor things but shows some of the frustration although minor. I believe with the renovations some of the issues will be resolved. 

 Internet was included by staying on the club level but we couldn't get internet in the seminar room. The company sponsoring the seminar would have had to pay additional for internet. This in this day and age is antiquated. Most hotels today provide free internet everywhere.<//Review>

< user_id>
112694612277741500883</user_id>
< Name>
Nancy Conrad<//Name>
< date>
1440179377356<//date>
<rate>1< /rate><review>Will never go back. Wherever do I start?
1. The valet parking staff sternly warned us that we were not to leave a car for more than 10 minutes in front of the hotel while we checked in or we'd be charged the valet parking fee - which is somewhere between $22 and $35 depending on what kind of deal you get. Mind you, there's no temporary parking area to leave your car other than the valet.

2. The room we were given had a bed that was so old the impressions of a thousand guests before me were obvious. The bathroom had black mold in the tile grout. There were plastic wrappings around the smoke alarm and the sprinkler system. (I'll post the pictures if I'm allowed here...)

3. We were assigned another room. Asked a staffer with a badge and a radio which way to go to find it, and he said, "I really don't know," and walked away. (Apparently staff was told: "Beatings will continue until morale improves.")

4. Second room key didn't work. Sat in the hall with our luggage while my spouse went downstairs to inquire at the main desk. By the way, there are no chairs in the hall or by the elevator. Good thing I'm not an old lady or handicapped.

5. Was given a THIRD room, which looked okay, and indeed had a comfy bed and reasonable bathroom. Only problem was that the desk chair was ripped, big time. Nobody noticed this before? I have pix of this too!

6. Spouse was given a restaurant credit for our many troubles, which we appreciated. However, when we went to use this credit, we were told that the restaurant was closed. This was 6 p.m on a Sunday night, and it's kinda standard to eat dinner 'bout this time. Was there another place where we could get dinner, we asked? Nope. That restaurant was closed too. Only option was to eat dinner in the bar during a large pool party. Lots of people stared at us while we ate at our tiny round table. Upside was that the food we did get was absolutely delicious and the staff was nice. Kudos to the chef.

7. Parking for this hotel, if you don't do the very expensive valet, is around the back in an open lot, about a block away from the entrance. That means you should probably leave your luggage with the valet (oh look, a tip!) if you don't want to schlep your bags quite a distance. The entrance to the parking does NOT SAY ANYTHING ABOUT SHERATON, so you must be psychic to figure out if this is the assigned parking area which we'd already paid for. There is a parking structure across the street from the hotel but this is NOT where you should go.

I'm not usually a big complainer, but there were so many fails at this place that I felt I must WARN YOU TO RUN, don't walk, to another place.<//review>< pictures>
None<//pictures>

< review>
Checked in on a Sunday night hoping to quickly get to sleep. Didn't know that there was going to be a loud party in the pool area till 10:30 PM. Got a room on that side of the hotel, and could hear the music pretty clearly until it finally shut off a little after 10:30 PM. When I called to inquire about the level of the music, at first I was told it would be done at midnight, and was hung up on. When I called again, the time had changed to 10:30 PM, and was hung up on again.

Woke up around 2-3 AM both nights I stayed to the strong taste and smell of cigarette smoke in my room. I think somebody was taking a smoke break near an air intake or something. Worst experience I've had at an SPG hotel by far. Also undergoing renovations, but aside from the valet being understaffed or overworked, I didn't notice any problems due to the renovation. I absolutely won't stay here again.< /review>

1373768327572</date>
< username>
Sean Elvidge</username>
< Pictures>
None</Pictures>
< Text>
I had a couple of meetings in LA and wanted to stay in a hotel near LAX. The Sheraton was perfect for this. The free shuttle bus between the hotel and airport runs every 10 mins or so and made travelling to and from the airport very easy. Inside I found the hotel to have professional and (extremely) helpful staff, comfortable and clean rooms and fantastic facilities around the hotel. The restaurants offered very high quality food and the pool area was nice to relax around. Even though the hotel is so close to the airport, you could barely, and rarely, hear noise from the planes. If I was to find any negative it would be that you had to pay for WiFi in the rooms, but this is a really great hotel. I will definitely stay again.< /Text>

< Rate>

<Review>The front desk staff works really hard to make sure that people feel welcomed and well served. The lobby is nice and there is a very convenient free shuttle service to LAX.

It is clear that this hotel has been around for a while. Although they have kept up with all the changes that Sheraton requires, greater investment is needed to get the hotel to where it should be. For example, the light shade in the room had been torn and would not sit properly on the light. In trying to adjust it, I noticed that several other people had tried to do this and there where many holes in it where others had tried to make it work. This is a small thing, but it points to a lack of care.

The rooms seemed clean and the beds were comfortable.

I would return because of the service and the access to LAX.< /Review>< pics>

< review>
This started several months ago when we attempted to reserve a room for a handicapped individual. Multiple phone calls still couldn't ensure that one of the occupants of the room would have a handicapped accessible shower, let alone the requisite refrigerator that was absolutely necessary. Two occupants were to use the room, both elderly women and one more handicapped than the other. It turns out the roll-in bed that one was expected to sleep in would be difficult for a small person to to be comfortable in, let alone an adult with back problems which were extremely exacerbated after one night spent on the bed. Fortunately, an astute member of the staff suggested a room change after multiple complaints about the telephone (see below) and the guests were transferred, including the refrigerator. The problem is that the refrigerator was not plugged in at its new destination, thereby ruining the contents.

The telephone at the first room only worked intermittently, as callers were unable to get through, despite the fact that neither occupant left the room the first day that they stayed in the hotel and they never realized that voicemails were being left. Complaints to the front desk were only addressed on the second day when a staffperson physically went to the room.

Finally, the valet service attempted to charge a 'fine' the final day (which was the price of one night's parking) because they claimed that they had not been informed of the room change, despite the fact that they managed to charge for the prior 3 days in the new room!<//review>

< Review>
I stay here frequently as an airline crew member. The rooms are very nice and the restaurant and bar are great. Front desk staff is not customer service focused and they are always understaffed no matter what time of day you check in. There was a planned water outage for maintenance which they knew about several days in advance.There was no verbal notification by front desk staff, and no attempt by staff to make it right. Staff does not seem to have authority to make decisions or solve problems. Night manager, Joaquin, did not try to solve the problem and said it "was above his pay grade". He also did not inform the front desk manager, Mary, about our complaints and inconvenience.< /Review>

112333480673286056131</userid>
< Pictures>
None< /Pictures>
< Rate>
4</Rate>
< text>
Nicely renovated hotel with a 24h lounge. Lounge had snacks but ran out of water at 10pm. Rooms are clean but the two rooms I booked were somewhat loud from the airplanes. One room was upgraded to an executive suite (I am Spg platinum) which was quite large and had a dining table which was nice as we had last minute thank you cards to finish. Good thing I am not too light of a sleeper as I was able to sleep through the noise despite the sounds of the planes landing and taking off. Parking is expensive here so I parked a block away at quikpark near the Hyatt regency.

A good airport hotel which is very close to terminal 1 if you wanted to walk it. Airplane noise could be a potential problem though.</text>

<Review>Everything with the hotel was fine, but the parking situation was a problem and caused both frustration and delay.

I stayed for 3 nights, and was given 2 passes for parking. Twice upon using the tickets to check out of the parking lot, I was given an error by the machine. Once I was able to call via the intercom and get buzzed out, but on the final day when trying to leave for a meeting, I was told to go back inside to get a new card, only to have the front desk tell me that the card should work and that I should try it again, only for it to fail again when I went back outside. Hotel needs to find a better solution to this, like using your room key, especially when they are charging it to the hotel anyway. The hotel was fine, but based on the parking issues alone I will be staying elsewhere on my next visit to Los Angeles.</Review>< pictures>

<text>I researched great pools and restaurants at hotels near LAX. Paparazzi at the Sheraton came up so I called to reserve a table for two to surprise my husband. 7 pm on Sunday was confirmed by hotel employee Jose. I then booked our room for our 24 hour getaway.

We check in. Room was average. No fridge. Then find out Paparazzi is closed on Sundays. When I called the front desk to ask how this could be, the hotel employee offered NO sympathy. Then a manager listened but offered no help.

We went to the hotel bar for our "fine dining" experience. The staff was very inattentive. I ordered an entree salad with no tomatoes and it came overflowing with tomatoes. When I picked them off, there was barely any salad left. It was disgusting.

<userid>105645647551872590801< /userid>< name>
Rocio Cotter<//name>
<Date>1406217483442</Date><Rating>1</Rating>< text>
I will start by saying that we will Not be returning to this location. We have stayed here for the last 5 years each year getting worst but out last visit was the worst.
We like this Sheraton because they offer the free shuttle to LAX, very convenient. But other hotels around offer the same service.
We arrived on Wednesday night to check in, our reservation a King Size Bedroom. The person at desk told us that the hotel was at full capacity and that we get 2 queen size beds. Already a bad start. I don't get why you have to make a reservation if when you show up they no longer have a room that fits your needs. A queen size bed for a person who is 6'4 means to sleep curled all night long if you stretch your legs will hang from this bed. We walk in the room, Room smells like smoke (it's a non smoking room) The room next to us, whoever was staying there was smoking weed you could smell it when we walked by.
They charge: $12.95 for 24 hours of basic internet.
Room service food not impressed for the prices. Paid $15 for a waffle. They charge $4.00 for delivery and a 16% charge ( you still have an option for additional tip )
I never mind the prices for room service and specially a place by the airport it's expected to be on the pricey side but the food is lacking so many things.

The outside of the hotel is trashed. When we walked in by the side there was empty bottles of vodka and tequila and plastic cups.

We have been part of the Sheraton point system since 2009 we have never gotten anything out of it.
I am very disappointed that big businesses like Sheraton try to give you crumbs for  what you pay for. Other businesses will try to give you at least a muffin or something so small to show that they care. Don't expect it from Sheraton.

I'm giving Sheraton LAX a one start only because the service people are nice.<//text>

<review>I booked the room at the last minute and I encountered a couple of inconveniences. When I first arrived there was no area to park unless you wanted to valet. There was not even an option to park temporarily to check in and figure out what options were available. I parked across the street in the banks parking structure. During the process of checking in I asked about parking options. The options were valet, I believe was $35 or using a parking lot that was used for airport travelers that was a little more then a block away. There was a voucher pass that was explained to me in the most confusing way that I ended up returning. I ended up using the airport parking and still had to pay to get out of the parking structure that I parked in to check in.

After parking and walking back with my luggage to the hotel, I went to my room. King sized bed, tv, ect.. The room was really nice. The bed on the other hand was uncomfortable and I found it difficult to sleep on. I am not a picky sleeper so for me to be uncomfortable there had to be an issue.

The bar was nice, reasonably priced drinks and the food was good.

Overall I dont think that I would stay at this location again, mainly the parking issue was the biggest factor and the most inconvenient.< /review><pics>None<//pics>< resp>

<gmapID>0x80c2b6d4e2d10a59:0x8fc3dc08704b5f1d< /gmapID><Resp>None<//Resp><name>Hkuraku<//name>< Review>
I stayed 4 nights here due to a convention I was attending nearby. This Sheraton doesn't offer the standard SPG basic membership things like free water bottles. There is a Starbucks in the lobby, which is convenient, since the LAX area is pretty barren. Staff was helpful/nice. Only a few things bothered me;

- My shower/tub was clogged
- My toilet was constantly running
- The connector door in my room was weird and was a weak point for noise. I shoved a towel in the gap of the door so I wouldn't hear everything my neighbor was doing
- (This last point is NO fault of the Sheraton's, just the area) There is no food nearby! Other than fast food and hotel food (which we all know is I overpriced for the quality)

Overall, not bad. The $14 wifi is a little silly though.</Review>

<text>We stayed here because we had an early morning flight, and they offer a free shuttle to the airport, which runs every 15 minutes. We turned in our car the night before to make the morning less stressful, and to avoid the ridiculous valet parking fee. Value for price was acceptable, but we do have a few negative comments. First, we made our reservation through the 800# and our rate included free WiFi. This was confirmed as we checked in. However, when we checked out, we had been charged $12.95, which we had some pushback getting them to fix. Second, there are soda machines but no snack machines anywhere on the property. Third, we went to the bar to have a drink. Ordered two Gin and Tonics and two Draft Beers. The bill came and it was $35! WOW! Finally, there is nowhere to park your car while you check in if you are leaving immediately or turning in a rental car. The valet insisted on taking our keys, even though we were only going to be inside for 5 minutes. After checking in, we came out and it took them 5 minutes to find our keys. There needs to be a lane or a few parking spaces that can be used for this purpose. Overall however, would choose again.< /text>< Time>

<review>I am a big starwood fan and was a little disappointed with my stay. I used my starwood points to book a night and that was an absolute waste. This was the first leg of my husbands and I honeymoon 2 days in LA - 6 days in Fiji then back to La. Clearly when we return to LA we wont be staying here. The room (Bathroom) was dirty upon our arrival, red stains in the sink , yellow stains on the towels, aweful water pressure for the shower. We later ordered room service which arrived COLD. Also when I checked in I informed then it was a part of our honeymoon and requested the club lounge floor, I was denied that request even as a spg member because I didnt select the upgrade online. I later asked if we could at least lounge in the club lounge until our flight left and the answer was no the manager would not even come out to acknowledge me. I will say the highlight was the restaurant our waiter was amazing and the food was pretty good, they even found margarine for my toast because I had a dairy allergy. 1373846400000< /date>
< rate>
None< /rate>
< text>
Checked in for a three-night stay & the front desk personnel were very courteous & professional. The facilities was very inviting especially the pool area. The room was great & we were able to control the temperature which is important. Throughout our stay 1) the card key did not work which is an inconvenience because I keep on asking the front desk to replace my card key & the issue was never resolved the whole time we we there although we were given some SPG points back; 2) the ice machine on our floor or the floor below us did not work for two days; 3) parking is offsite and could be an inconvenience for guests who do not wish to valet park. When I registered into the hotel there was no parking available & the shuttle bust drivers were very rude to my wife who waited in the standing car while I checked-in. Also if the parking lot charges $11 for 24 hours Sheraton charges $17/day, if the hotel doesn't own the lot would have been nice to get a discount. Also the bar munchies were stale, I could have spent more money. Overall our stay could have been better if the issues I brought up were addressed, I doubt I will stay here again.<//text>
